header.title: LIBER #91 Mixed Feelings: Personal & Confidential (Superior Degree Conventicles 21-24)
authors: The International College of Esoteric Studies

central_thesis: This text provides a structured curriculum for the Martinist Superior Degree, aiming to guide students toward mystical enlightenment and self-mastery through deep study and practical application of Qabalistic principles, the Tree of Life, and exploration of the Astral Plane. The ultimate goal is the reintegration of the individual consciousness with the Divine, understanding the 'I AM THAT I AM'.

structure_content.chapter_title: Conventicle 21: Foundations in Sepher Yetzirah and Supernal Triad
structure_content.summary: Introduces the Sepher Yetzirah as a source for understanding numbers and creation, focusing on factorials as 'theosophic multiplication'. Explores the first three Sephiroth (Kether, Chokmah, Binah) as the Supernal Triad, representing Gnosis, That Which Knows, and That By Which It Is Known. It emphasizes their interconnectedness and the concept of Divine manifestation, linking them to ancient Egyptian cosmology and the ratio of 22:7 (Pi).

Recaps the Four Realms (Atziluth, Briah, Yetzirah, Assiah) and their Martinist correspondences. Discusses the three Pillars of the Tree of Life (Mercy, Severity, Middle Pillar) and introduces 'Pathworking' as an operative technique for traversing the Tree. Warns about the dangers of fascination on the Astral Plane and suggests practical self-purification methods like the 'Magic Mirror' and dream analysis.

structure_content.chapter_title: Conventicle 23: Tarot, Christ Power, and Linguistic Roots
structure_content.summary: Continues the discussion on Tarot, linking its suits to the Qabalistic Realms and its figures (King, Queen, Knight, Knave) to the Yod-He-Vau-He principle. Explores the concept of 'Christ Power' or the 'Fifth Essence' as achieved through Cosmic Communion. Emphasizes the importance of the Hebrew language for understanding ancient occult mysteries and provides instructions for an Astral meditation exercise focusing on the nape of the neck.

structure_content.chapter_title: Conventicle 24: Kether, Meditation Practice, and Order's History
structure_content.summary: Reiterates Kether as the 'Point within the Circle' and the source of creation, presenting its various Qabalistic names. Prescribes a meditation practice involving focusing on a chosen symbol (Crown/Point within a Circle), projecting it to the nape of the neck, and recording sleep experiences. Signals the upcoming study of the Order's history, highlighting the progressive, experiential nature of Martinist teachings.

structure_content.chapter_title: Notes for Students 'Ten': Recap of Qabalistic Stages
structure_content.summary: Summarizes the Qabalistic stages prior to Manifestation (Ain, Ain Soph, Ain Soph Aur), the First Point (Kether), the Four Realms, and the roles of the Sephiroth within these realms. Outlines the individual's Path of Return through the Tree of Life and the concept of Adam Qadmon.

structure_content.chapter_title: Notes for Students 'Eleven': The Astral Plane and Pathworking Dangers
structure_content.summary: Defines the Astral Plane as the 'realm of visual imagination' or 'level of the mind' where energies take form, emphasizing its reality and influence. Details the dangers of Pathworking, particularly 'fascination,' and the necessity of self-discipline and purification to avoid negative psychological or physical consequences.

structure_content.chapter_title: Notes for Students 'Thirteen': Sephirothic Attributions and Practical Work
structure_content.summary: Discusses the various attributions of the Sephiroth, stressing that true understanding comes from practical work (meditation, contemplation, prayer) rather than mere intellectual study. Highlights the divine inspiration of Hebrew Names and Archangels associated with the Sephiroth, providing an example from Genesis XVIII:2, and encourages personal experimentation and internal authority in esoteric practice.

key_concepts.definition: An ancient Hebrew treatise explaining creation through numbers and letters, foundational to Qabalistic understanding of Divine emanation and natural laws. It's used to derive 'theosophic multiplication' and understanding of factorials.

Comprising Kether (Crown), Chokmah (Wisdom), and Binah (Understanding), these are the first three Sephiroth, considered the core of Reality and representing 'Gnosis, That Which Knows, and That By Which It Is Known'. They form the 'Martinist World of God'.

Described as the 'realm of visual imagination' or a 'level of the mind' where psychic energies take form. It is considered 'REAL' and profoundly influences human experience; conscious interaction with it requires self-discipline due to potential dangers like 'fascination'.

An operative technique for 'entering or travelling the Paths' on the Tree of Life. It involves projecting one's mind-self into symbolic situations or landscapes to gain self-knowledge and inner perception, serving as a practical tool for spiritual ascent.

A self-examination technique involving a notebook divided into 'Fortunate Mirror' (positive characteristics) and 'Unfortunate Mirror' (negative characteristics) to ruthlessly observe oneself, identify patterns, and learn emotional control as a method of self-purification.

A fundamental principle representing Positive, Negative, Neuter, and Transition, applied to the four suits of the Tarot, numerical cycles, and symbolic illustrations of cosmic processes and human evolution. It is also related to the Hebrew spelling of IESCHOUAH (Christ Power).

The First Sephirah on the Tree of Life, representing Unity, the Source, the 'Point within the Circle,' and the Indivisible Self (Yekhidah). It is considered the control point for everything external and subordinate, existing beyond our cosmos but as its underlying basis.

The three grades of the soul in Qabalistic thought: Nefesh (gross element, instincts), Ruah (moral virtues, discernment of good/evil), and Neshamah (sublimest grade, divine breath, intuitive knowledge, highest phase of existence, identified with Shekhinah).

The Divine Man or Archetypal Man, a macrocosmic representation with polarities at the Head and feet on Earth, symbolizing the collective reintegration that man must achieve in his Path of Return to the Divine.

practical_system.description: The system combines theoretical Qabalistic and Martinist study with a progressive set of operative practices focused on inner transformation and energetic engagement. It is designed to lead the student from intellectual understanding to direct spiritual experience, emphasizing self-discipline, ethical conduct, and diligent record-keeping as prerequisites for effective work in the inner realms. The core involves 'Pathworking' on the Tree of Life, astral exploration, and various forms of meditation and self-reflection.
tools: Notebook ('Magic Mirror'): Essential for recording self-observations, dreams, and meditative experiences, creating a personal 'Book of Man'.
Tree of Life Diagram: A visual aid for mapping Sephiroth, Paths, and their various attributions for study and pathworking.
Tarot Cards (Major Arcana): Utilized as symbolic representations of the 22 Paths on the Tree of Life for pathworking and meditation.
Hebrew Alphabet & Divine Names: Crucial for Qabalistic study, understanding creation, and for use in invocations and meditations.
Chosen Symbols (Crown, Point within a Circle): Used as focal points for specific meditation practices to concentrate awareness and intent.
Reference Texts: Sepher Yetzirah, works by Dion Fortune, Charles Ponce, Gareth Knight, Papus, and Edouard Shure are cited as authoritative sources for theoretical study.
rituals: Meditation on Sephirothic concepts and Divine Names: Focused contemplation on specific Sephiroth, their attributes, and associated Hebrew names to deepen understanding and connection.

Astral Journey / Pathworking: A controlled, disciplined technique for projecting one's 'mind-self' into symbolic landscapes or situations on the Paths of the Tree of Life or the Astral Plane for insight and experience.

Mystic Degree Exercise (Astral Work): A specific meditation involving sitting quietly, eyes closed, turning the gaze inward, focusing on the nape of the neck, and mentally requesting to reach a desired level of the unconscious.

Self-Examination ('Magic Mirror'): A daily journaling practice where positive ('Fortunate Mirror') and negative ('Unfortunate Mirror') characteristics are recorded to observe oneself, identify patterns, and develop self-control.
Dream Analysis: Recording dreams immediately upon waking to gain insights from the unconscious mind and for self-purification, emphasizing personal interpretation over external guides.

Invocation to Omneity/Eheyeh: Using specific invocations (e.g., 'O Thou Host Mysterious and Recondite King of all above and below, whose name we call in love Eheyeh, protect us with a ring of light that in Thy light we may know Light. Amen.') during meditation with a chosen symbol.

relevant_quotes.text: The International College of Esoteric Studies Inc., is a registered non-profit institution and exists for the purpose of disseminating information on the Traditional Esoteric Arcaria. The lectures/instruction contained in this Liber comprise material which was previously delivered orally to an esoteric group and has subsequently been given to the College for its use. Under these circumstances the College does not claim to be the author or originator of the contents of this Liber which is distributed in good faith. This Liber is loaned, not sold, to the receiving member as an incident of membership, for personal and private study, and its acceptance by the student is an acknowledgement that it is being held in trust for the College and is to be returned to it upon request.

"For my thoughts are not your thoughts, neither are your ways, my ways; saith the Lord." (Chap 55: 8-9). "For as the heavens are higher than the earth, so are my ways higher than your ways, and my thoughts than your thoughts."

Section 16: "Two stones build two houses, three stones build six houses, four stones build twenty-four houses, five build 120 houses, six build 720 houses, and seven build 5040 houses. From thence, go further, and reckon what the mouth cannot express and the ear cannot hear."

"I was alone, for nothing had been brought forth; I had not then emitted from myself Shu or Tefnut. I evolved myself; I emitted from myself the gods Shu and Tefnut and, from being One, I became Three; they sprang from me and came into existence in this Earth: Shu and Tefnut brought forth Seb and Nut; and Nut brought forth Osiris, Horus-Khent-an-maa, Nephtys, Set and Isis at one birth."

"The first three Sephiroth, Crown, Wisdom, Intellect, ought to be considered as the sole and same thing. The first represents GNOSIS (that is, final unconditioned awareness), - the second that which knows, and the third, that by which it is known. The knowledge of the Creator is not that of the creatures; On the contrary, the Creator is Itself wholly at the same time, Knowledge, That which Knows, and That Which is Known."

The mystical student often hears of the 32 Paths of Wisdom. These are the 10 Holy Sephiroth, which are both cosmic foci and psychic powers, and the 22 Paths linking them on the Tree of Life. The Sephiroth are in a sense objective, since they are externalized powers in thought at least, whereas the 22 Paths between them are subjective and are a mode of applying oneself to these 10 Spheres. There is a method of "treading" these Paths called "Pathworking" which is a technique that all occult students concern themselves with and this will occupy our attention in due time.

The words 'Astral' and 'mind' have been used synonomously. Eliphas Levi, writing in his History of Magic, said: "The composite form of the sphinx also represents by hieroglyphical analogy the four properties of the universal agent, that is to say, the Astral Light - dissolving, coagulating, heating and cooling. These four properties, directed by the will of man, can modify all phases of Nature, producing life or death, health or disease, love or hatred, wealth even or poverty, in accordance with the given impulsion."

critical_analysis.relevance: This work is highly relevant for students of Western Esotericism, particularly those interested in Martinist and Qabalistic traditions. It provides a foundational understanding of the Tree of Life, Sephiroth, and the Astral Plane, bridging theoretical knowledge with practical, operative exercises. The emphasis on self-discipline, inner work, and the dangers of uncontrolled astral exploration aligns with responsible occult practice, offering a systematic path for mystical development. The integration of various esoteric currents (Qabalah, Egyptian, Christian, Astrological, Tarot) within a coherent framework makes it a valuable teaching text for an order.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience is 'Students of the Superior Degree' within the Ordre Martiniste or 'The International College of Esoteric Studies'. It is designed for serious practitioners committed to a structured path of self-knowledge and mystical enlightenment, explicitly warning against a purely intellectual approach and encouraging direct experiential engagement. The content is 'Personal & Confidential', implying an initiated or advanced student body.
